name: Poverty Headcount ($1.25 a day)
sourceNote: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income below the poverty line.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Under Middle Class ($10 a day) Headcount
sourceNote: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income below the poverty line.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Poverty Headcount ($2.50 a day)
sourceNote: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income below the poverty line.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Middle Class ($10-50 a day) Headcount
sourceNote: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income below the poverty line.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Official Moderate Poverty Rate-National
sourceNote: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income below the poverty line.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of data from National Statistical Offices.

name: Poverty Headcount ($4 a day)
sourceNote: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income below the poverty line.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Vulnerable ($4-10 a day) Headcount
sourceNote: The poverty headcount index measures the proportion of the population with daily per capita income below the poverty line.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Poverty Gap ($1.25 a day)
sourceNote: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the poverty line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the poverty line (averaged over the total population).
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Under Middle Class ($10 a day) Gap
sourceNote: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the $10/day line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the $10 line (averaged over the total population).
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Poverty Gap ($2.50 a day)
sourceNote: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the poverty line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the poverty line (averaged over the total population).
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Middle Class ($10-50 a day) Gap
sourceNote: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the $10/day line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the $10 line (averaged over the total population).

name: Poverty Gap ($4 a day)
sourceNote: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the poverty line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the poverty line (averaged over the total population).

name: Vulnerable ($4-10 a day) Gap
sourceNote: The poverty gap captures the mean aggregate income or consumption shortfall relative to the vulnerable line across the entire population. It measures the total resources needed to bring all the poor to the level of the vulnerable line (averaged over the total population).
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Poverty Severity ($1.25 a day)
sourceNote: The poverty severity index combines information on both poverty and inequality among the poor by averaging the squares of the poverty gaps relative the poverty line
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Coverage: Completing 6th grade on time
sourceNote: The coverage rate is the average access rate of a given opportunity used in calculating the Human Opportunities Index (HOI). The coverage rate does not take into account inequality of access between different circumstance groups.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: HOI: Completing 6th grade on time
sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, household per capita income, number of siblings, presence of both parents in the household, gender of the household head, and urban or rural residence.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: HOI: Mobile Phone
sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, household per capita income, number of siblings, presence of both parents in the household, gender of the household head, and urban or rural residence.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, household per capita income, number of siblings, presence of both parents in the household, gender of the household head, and urban or rural residence.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: HOI: Internet
sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, household per capita income, number of siblings, presence of both parents in the household, gender of the household head, and urban or rural residence.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.

name: HOI: Mathematics Proficiency Level 2
sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, region of school location, father's occupation, and a household wealth index based on assets.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations using PISA Data.

sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, region of school location, father's occupation, and a household wealth index based on assets.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations using PISA Data.

name: HOI: Reading Proficiency Level 3, Private schools
sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. name: HOI: Sanitation
sourceNote: The Human Opportunities Index (HOI) is an economic indicator that captures the degree of inequality of access to an essential service by different circumstance groups. This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, household per capita income, number of siblings, presence of both parents in the household, gender of the household head, and urban or rural residence.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

This index takes into account the average access rate (the coverage) of a given opportunity (service) and the inequality of its distribution. The circumstances included in the HOI are the gender of the child, parents' education, household per capita income, number of siblings, presence of both parents in the household, gender of the household head, and urban or rural residence.An increase in the index can be related either to an increase in the coverage or to a more equal distribution of that service.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Atkinson, A(.5)
sourceNote: Atkinson (1970) proposed this class of inequality measures with  a weighting parameter ε which measures aversion to inequality. As ε rises, the index becomes more sensitive to transfers at the lower end of the distribution and less sensitive to transfers at the top. The limit case, ε→0, the index reflects the Function of Rawls which only takes account of transfers to the very lowest income group; at the other extreme, when ε=0, we obtain the linear utility function. This ranks distributions solely according to total income.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Atkinson, A(1)
sourceNote: Atkinson (1970) proposed this class of inequality measures with  a weighting parameter ε which measures aversion to inequality. As ε rises, the index becomes more sensitive to transfers at the lower end of the distribution and less sensitive to transfers at the top. The limit case, ε→0, the index reflects the Function of Rawls which only takes account of transfers to the very lowest income group; at the other extreme, when ε=0, we obtain the linear utility function. This ranks distributions solely according to total income.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Atkinson, A(2)
sourceNote: Atkinson (1970) proposed this class of inequality measures with  a weighting parameter ε which measures aversion to inequality. As ε rises, the index becomes more sensitive to transfers at the lower end of the distribution and less sensitive to transfers at the top. The limit case, ε→0, the index reflects the Function of Rawls which only takes account of transfers to the very lowest income group; at the other extreme, when ε=0, we obtain the linear utility function. This ranks distributions solely according to total income.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Generalized Entrophy, GE(-1)
sourceNote: The parameter α in the GE class represents the weight given to distances between incomes at different parts of the income distribution, and can take any real value. For lower values of α, GE is more sensitive to changes in the lower tail of the distribution, and for higher values GE is more sensitive to changes that affect the upper tail. GE(1) is the Theil index.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Generalized Entrophy, GE(2)
sourceNote: The parameter α in the GE class represents the weight given to distances between incomes at different parts of the income distribution, and can take any real value. For lower values of α, GE is more sensitive to changes in the lower tail of the distribution, and for higher values GE is more sensitive to changes that affect the upper tail. GE(1) is the Theil index.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Gini Coefficient
sourceNote: The Gini coefficient is most common measure of inequality. It is based on the Lorenz curve, a cumulative frequency curve that compares the distribution of a specific variable (in this case, income) with the uniform distribution that represents equality. The Gini coefficient is bounded by 0 (indicating perfect equality of income) and 1, which means complete inequality. This calculation includes observations of 0 income.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Gini Coefficient (No Zero Income)
sourceNote: The Gini coefficient is most common measure of inequality. It is based on the Lorenz curve, a cumulative frequency curve that compares the distribution of a specific variable (in this case, income) with the uniform distribution that represents equality. The Gini coefficient is bounded by 0 (indicating perfect equality of income) and 1, which means complete inequality. This calculation does not includes observations of 0 income.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Income Share of First Quintile
sourceNote: Share of household income held by the bottom quintile (0-20 percent).
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Income Share of Second Quintile
sourceNote: Share of household income held by the seocnd quintile (20 - 40 percent).
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Income Share of Third Quintile
sourceNote: Share of household income held by the third quintile (40 - 60 percent).
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Income Share of Fourth Quintile
sourceNote: Share of household income held by the fourth quintile (60 - 80 percent).
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Income Share of Fifth Quintile
sourceNote: Share of household income held by the top quintile (80 - 100 percent).
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Mean Log Deviation, GE(0)
sourceNote: The parameter α in the GE class represents the weight given to distances between incomes at different parts of the income distribution, and can take any real value. For lower values of α, GE is more sensitive to changes in the lower tail of the distribution, and for higher values GE is more sensitive to changes that affect the upper tail. GE(1) is the Theil index.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Rate 75/25
sourceNote: The decile dispersion ratio presents the ratio of the average income of the richest 25 percent by that of the poorest 25 percent. This ratio expresses the income of the top quantile as multiples of that of the poorest quantile. However, it ignores information about incomes in the middle of the income distribution and doesn’t use information about the distribution of income within the top and bottom deciles or percentiles.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Rate 90/10
sourceNote: The decile dispersion ratio presents the ratio of the average income of the richest 10 percent by that of the poorest 10 percent. This ratio expresses the income of the top quantile as multiples of that of the poorest quantile. However, it ignores information about incomes in the middle of the income distribution and doesn’t use information about the distribution of income within the top and bottom deciles or percentiles.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Theil Index, GE(1)
sourceNote: The Theil index is part of a larger family of measures referred to as the General Entropy class. Compared to the Gini index, it has the advantage of being additive across different subgroups or regions in the country. However, it does not have a straightforward representation and lacks the appealing interpretation of the Gini coefficient.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Gini, Rural
sourceNote: The Gini coefficient is most common measure of inequality. It is based on the Lorenz curve, a cumulative frequency curve that compares the distribution of a specific variable (in this case, income) with the uniform distribution that represents equality. The Gini coefficient is bounded by 0 (indicating perfect equality of income) and 1, which means complete inequality. This calculation includes observations of 0 income.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Mean Log Deviation, GE(0), Rural
sourceNote: The parameter α in the GE class represents the weight given to distances between incomes at different parts of the income distribution, and can take any real value. For lower values of α, GE is more sensitive to changes in the lower tail of the distribution, and for higher values GE is more sensitive to changes that affect the upper tail. GE(1) is the Theil index.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Theil Index, GE(1), Rural
sourceNote: The Theil index is part of a larger family of measures referred to as the General Entropy class. Compared to the Gini index, it has the advantage of being additive across different subgroups or regions in the country. However, it does not have a straightforward representation and lacks the appealing interpretation of the Gini coefficient.
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of SEDLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: GINI, Urban

sourceNote: The parameter α in the GE class represents the weight given to distances between incomes at different parts of the income distribution, and can take any real value. For lower values of α, GE is more sensitive to changes in the lower tail of the distribution, and for higher values GE is more sensitive to changes that affect the upper tail. name: Theil Index, GE(1),Urban
sourceNote: The Theil index is part of a larger family of measures referred to as the General Entropy class. Compared to the Gini index, it has the advantage of being additive across different subgroups or regions in the country. However, it does not have a straightforward representation and lacks the appealing interpretation of the Gini coefficient.

name: Labor Income Poverty Index
sourceNote: The Labor Income Poverty Index (LIPI) uses only labor income to construct an index of poverty. Based on a reference period, the index calculates the population reporting labor income that is below the poverty line relative to a selected reference period
sourceOrganization: LAC Equity Lab tabulations of LABLAC (CEDLAS and the World Bank).

name: Income share held by second 20%
sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

name: Income share held by third 20%
sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.

Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

name: Poverty headcount ratio at $2 a day (PPP) (% of population)
sourceNote: Population below $2 a day is the percentage of the population living on less than $2.00 a day at 2005 international prices. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

name: Poverty headcount ratio at $1.25 a day (PPP) (% of population)
sourceNote: Population below $1.25 a day is the percentage of the population living on less than $1.25 a day at 2005 international prices. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

name: Poverty gap at $2 a day (PPP) (%)
sourceNote: Poverty gap is the mean shortfall from the poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

name: Poverty gap at $1.25 a day (PPP) (%)
sourceNote: Poverty gap is the mean shortfall from the poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

name: GINI index (World Bank estimate)
sourceNote: Gini index measures the extent to which the distribution of income or consumption expenditure among individuals or households within an economy deviates from a perfectly equal distribution. A Lorenz curve plots the cumulative percentages of total income received against the cumulative number of recipients, starting with the poorest individual or household. The Gini index measures the area between the Lorenz curve and a hypothetical line of absolute equality, expressed as a percentage of the maximum area under the line. Thus a Gini index of 0 represents perfect equality, while an index of 100 implies perfect inequality.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

name: Poverty gap at national poverty lines (%)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are compiled from official government sources or are computed by World Bank staff using national (i.e. country–specific) poverty lines.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

name: Poverty headcount ratio at national poverty lines (% of population)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are compiled from official government sources or are computed by World Bank staff using national (i.e. country–specific) poverty lines.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

name: Rural poverty gap at national poverty lines (%)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are compiled from official government sources or are computed by World Bank staff using national (i.e. country–specific) poverty lines.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

name: Rural poverty headcount ratio at national poverty lines (% of rural population)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are compiled from official government sources or are computed by World Bank staff using national (i.e. country–specific) poverty lines.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

name: Urban poverty gap at national poverty lines (%)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are compiled from official government sources or are computed by World Bank staff using national (i.e. country–specific) poverty lines.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

name: Urban poverty headcount ratio at national poverty lines (% of urban population)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are compiled from official government sources or are computed by World Bank staff using national (i.e. country–specific) poverty lines.
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

name: Survey mean consumption or income per capita, bottom 40% (2005 PPP $ per day)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Database of Shared Prosperity (GDSP) circa 2006 - 2011 (http://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/poverty/brief/global-database-of-shared-prosperity).
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Database of Shared Prosperity (GDSP) circa 2006 - 2011.

name: Annualized growth in survey mean consumption or income per capita, bottom 40% (%, based on 2005 PPP)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Database of Shared Prosperity (GDSP) circa 2006 - 2011 (http://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/poverty/brief/global-database-of-shared-prosperity).
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Database of Shared Prosperity (GDSP) circa 2006 - 2011.

name: Survey mean consumption or income per capita, total population (2005 PPP $ per day)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Database of Shared Prosperity (GDSP) circa 2006 - 2011 (http://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/poverty/brief/global-database-of-shared-prosperity).
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Database of Shared Prosperity (GDSP) circa 2006 - 2011.

name: Annualized growth in survey mean consumption or income per capita, total population (%, based on 2005 PPP)
sourceNote: World Bank, Global Database of Shared Prosperity (GDSP) circa 2006 - 2011 (http://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/poverty/brief/global-database-of-shared-prosperity).
sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Database of Shared Prosperity (GDSP) circa 2006 - 2011.
